 On questions relating to the Bible's treatment of family and morals, one might expect assurance, if not rigidity, from Evangelical Christianity. So, it may surprise many to learn how "live" the topic of divorce remains in Evangelical circles. Last month, the cover story of the monthly Christianity Today was titled "When to Separate What God has Joined: A Closer Reading on the Bible on Divorce." The heated controversy provoked by the story showed how Biblically flexible some Evangelicals can be - especially when God's word seems at odds not just with modern American behavior, but also with simple human kindness. 
 
 As the article's author, the British Evangelical scholar David Instone-Brewer, points out, for most of 2,000 years Christians have viewed divorce through two scriptural citations. In Matthew, the pharisees ask Christ, "Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife for any cause?" Jesus refers to the Old Testament and then replies, "Whoever divorces a wife, except for sexual indecency, commits adultery." The apostle Paul adds in the book First Corinthians that a Christian is "not bound" to a non-Christian spouse who abandons him. Simple, right?
 
 Instone-Brewer radically reinterprets the first passage using, of all things, quotation marks. The Greek of the New Testament didn't always contain them, and scholars agree that sometimes they must be added in to make sense of it. Instone-Brewer, an expert in Jewish thought during Jesus's era, writes that Christ's interlocutors were not asking him whether there was any cause at all for divorce, but whether he supported something called "any-cause" divorce, a term a little bit like "no-fault" that allowed husbands to divorce wives for any reason at all. Instone-Brewer claims Jesus's "no" was a response to this idea, and that his "except for sexual indecency" condition was not a statement of the sole exemption from God's blanket prohibition, but merely Christ's reiteration of one of several divorce permissions in the Old Testament - one he felt the "any-time" advocates had exaggerated. Finally, Instone-Brewer tallies four grounds for divorce he finds affirmed in both Old and New Testaments: adultery, emotional and sexual neglect, abandonment (by anyone) and abuse.
 
 Christianity Today has written previously on divorce, often bemoaning how easy it is in today's America. However, the Instone-Brewer essay appeared to be its editors' attempt to offer Evangelicals an escape from a classic dilemma. The "plain sense" of Jesus's words without quotes seems clear enough, but also inhumane: how could a loving God forbid divorce, even by omission, in cases of wife-beating, or of abandonment by a Christian spouse?http://news.yahoo.com/s/time/20071106/us_time/anevangelicalrethinkondivorce

"some marriages, God didn't put together. So it's okay to divorce."
 
 quote from Pentecostal congregationist I spoke with once.
 
 "some people just grow apart."
 
 another quote from a 2nd evangelical fundy.
 
 1 Corin 7:15
 But if the unbeliever leaves, let him do so. A believing man or woman is not bound in such circumstances; God has called us to live in peace.
 
 Some have twisted this passage and call to 'live in peace' to justify divorce amongst a believer EVEN when the non-believer didn't want a seperation. Placing emphasis on what the believer is experiencing over any other concerns. Taken out of context, the believer can NOT be in peace if their unbelieving spouse is causing them problems (real OR imagined). Thus, it'd be best to divorce the unbeliever.
 
 Pretty radical eisegesis but, it happens often. I've seen it several times with some fundy groups.
 
 Also, a shrewd reading on the bible could leave you with the impression that it is okay to seperate and divorce BUT, the only way you can remarry anyone else (and not have it considered adultry) is due to infidelity.
 So couple AB could split up and if B engaged or engages in infidelity (even when divorced) then A is free. 1 Corin 7:10-11
 To the married I give this command (not I, but the Lord): A wife must not separate from her husband. But if she does, she must remain unmarried or else be reconciled to her husband. And a husband must not divorce his wife.
 
 Some people have taken advantage of this as 1 Corinthians also speaks about what can happen when seperation occurs...one partner may stumble and 'cheat'.
 7:5-6 Do not deprive each other except by mutual consent and for a time, so that you may devote yourselves to prayer. Then come together again so that Satan will not tempt you because of your lack of self-control. I say this as a concession, not as a command. 
 
 
 In the end, it's my personal finding that most people will grasp at anything to support their desires. Even the bible is twisted (or not) to support what they want. 
 My favorite twisting is by the Word of Faith movement (health wealth prosperity cult) that pretty much says the riches of the evil are there for the loyal followers of God to claim...basically supporting the notion that it's OKAY to steal...provided that you're doing so from a 'bad guy'.
 I've seen it done.
 Awsome!

 We fret about excommunication from churches we aren't members of? Well, that's news. Of course what happens within one church or another isn't directly relevant to those of us that church has no influence over. But it doesn't stop there, does it.
 
 The RC church, for example, and it is not unique among Christian churches, have regularly interfered with secular politics, threatening to excommunicate Catholic politicians who do not vote the way their pope tells them to. They agitate for laws that would infringe the rights of non-believers in their doctrines -- homosexuality, abortion, right-to-die, stem cell research and contraception are just some of the issues about which religious believers would try to compel others to follow their beliefs.
 
 So it's pretty naive to claim that the policies and doctrines of a church are insignificant to non-believers, when believers are trying hell for leather to turn them into public policy that affects non-believers.

 There are several mainstream theists here, myself, Steeeeve, Jo Bennett, and probably others too that I can't think of. I think atheists have a point in their concerns about people working toward getting their religious beliefs out into law by direct legislation. I agree with the atheists here on some of this--such as an amendment prohibiting gay marriage, which is unnecessary. But I think we have to be very careful in terms of what we consider 'allowable' and not in terms of people having latitude of participating in the process. It would be useful to hear from atheists here as to what extent they think theists should abstain from taking part in the political process. For instance, does this mean their opposition is limited to Christians promoting direct prohibitive legislation? Or do they think people should somehow check their religion at the door of the voting booth and not vote with any religiously-influenced conscience?
lesz

There are several mainstream theists here, myself, Steeeeve, Jo Bennett, and probably others too that I can't think of. I think atheists have a point in their concerns about people working toward getting their religious beliefs out into law by direct legislation. I agree with the atheists here on some of this--such as an amendment prohibiting gay marriage, which is unnecessary. But I think we have to be very careful in terms of what we consider 'allowable' and not in terms of people having latitude of participating in the process. It would be useful to hear from atheists here as to what extent they think theists should abstain from taking part in the political process. For instance, does this mean their opposition is limited to Christians promoting direct prohibitive legislation? Or do they think people should somehow check their religion at the door of the voting booth and not vote with any religiously-influenced conscience?

 
 I'm not arguing that religious believers abstain from the political process. I am suggesting that the political process be limited to secular issues, rather than religiously doctrinal ones. If some religious people have a problem of conscience about some activity, then it is perfectly appropriate for them to abstain from that activity. 
 
 If they want to support legislation preventing others from partaking in that activity, then it is incumbent upon them to demonstrate how that activity harms society as a whole, rather than just infringing their religious doctrines.
 
 Some moral issues are so transcendent, that society needs to legislate against them: e.g. murder, theft. There is a genuine, secular need there. Others are much less so, such as gay marriage or the form of religious service.
 
 There will always be issues in the middle, such as abortion or stem cell research. As long as there is no overwhelming consensus in society, liberty of choice is the preferred option. 
 
 I am a great believer in respect for life, if only because it is so rare, unusual and contingent. However, that also has to include respect for dissent. Some issues are clearcut, such as murder. It is certainly not at all clearcut that abortion is murder. There has to be room left for dissent here, because intolerance of dissent is contrary to respect for life. Confused? Well, the question is confusing, and it's because there isn't a single right answer that we have to be flexible.
jyoshu

I'm not arguing that religious believers abstain from the political process. I am suggesting that the political process be limited to secular issues, rather than religiously doctrinal ones. 
 
 There will always be issues in the middle, such as abortion or stem cell research. As long as there is no overwhelming consensus in society, liberty of choice is the preferred option. 

 
 Well, there you go. It just so happens that the issues "in the middle" are often the ones that people such as yourself tend to think religious people are trying to legislate. So what it is, specifically, you think religious people should limit themselves from in terms of the political process? Should they put a "religious-issue" litmus test on voting, and not vote for candidates who would support such legislation? Where do you draw the line? Just not circulate petitions? All of the above? Or again, should it be limited to cases where prohibitive legislation is involved?
Kronus

Should they put a "religious-issue" litmus test on voting, and not vote for candidates who would support such legislation? Where do you draw the line? Just not circulate petitions? All of the above? Or again, should it be limited to cases where prohibitive legislation is involved?

 
 You're glossing over one of the fundamental dichotomies of our political system. The rights of the people to vote, express opinions, and engage in the political process should not, must not, be infringed. At the same time, people have the responsibility to elect officials who one may reasonably hope will uphold the law and defend the constitution. But, and this is a big but, they don't have to. If our freedoms are going to mean anything, they unfortunately must include the freedom to be stupid. So while there are lots of things voters should do, it's fundamental to our system that nothing be done to insure that they do it. So while I could come up with a whole laundry list of things that the overly religious should or should not do in the policical arena there's not an item on the list that I would see imposed upon them. Government officials, naturally, are a totally different issue. They I expect to follow the constitution.
jyoshu

jyoshu

 Well, FWIW, I actually agree with you on the last one in general, though it's a very general statement. I think religious people should mind their own business more and not be so concerned with the actions of others (in terms of social issues).
lesz

Well, there you go. It just so happens that the issues "in the middle" are often the ones that people such as yourself tend to think religious people are trying to legislate. So what it is, specifically, you think religious people should limit themselves from in terms of the political process? Should they put a "religious-issue" litmus test on voting, and not vote for candidates who would support such legislation? Where do you draw the line? Just not circulate petitions? All of the above? Or again, should it be limited to cases where prohibitive legislation is involved?

 
 Individuals are going to vote for whatever policies they prefer for their own, idiosyncratic reasons. That's why we need limitations on what government can legitimately do, and those limitations need to be tightest in areas where religious and moral opinions differ widely and strongly.
 
 If religious fanatics get their way and have government legislate against everything they deem "immoral", then what you have is a theocracy or religious tyranny, not a republic of free individuals. When someone supports some legislation purely because "my god opposes this activity", then we need to be very suspicious about it, and government activity in that area ought to be highly circumscribed. 
 
 And yes, no-one should vote for candidates who would enshrine religious doctrine in law. That would be a very unwise vote, leading ultimately to theocracy and away from a constitutional republic.
 
 And such argument would also apply to any legislation brought against religion. The best scenario is to keep politics and government out of religion entirely, for or against. Once politicians start beating the religious drums, they degrade everything about religion and politics both.
